page.title: 14ECOLOGY
page.content: {ECOLOGY }North Leverton is on the west side of the Trent. The hills to the west protect the area from most heavy snow falls except when from the east. The soil is slow to warm up in the spring but retains moisture in summer because of the heavy clay. Farms are approx 100 hectares in size and generally arable. Footpaths were common but now are little used. Pollution level low, despite being in sight of power staions. The beck has stickle backs and eels, but being shallow until heavy rainfall water life can change quickly. The windmill has been used to grind corn for over 100 years. Recreation fields are kept trimmed and open spaces kept in good order. It was known as an orchard village but most orchards have been developed but new trees are being planted.
